Understate: The claim may understate the fact that the marginal tax rate for high-earning individuals or families in 1980 was not 70% for all income, but rather applied to incomes above a certain threshold.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks specific evidence or data to support the assertion that the marginal tax rate for high-earning individuals or families in 1980 was 70%.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the 70% marginal tax rate in 1980 is directly comparable to the proposed tax rates mentioned by Rep. Ocasio-Cortez, without considering potential differences in tax brackets or income thresholds.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations or factors that may have influenced the marginal tax rate in 1980, such as economic conditions or political considerations.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the highest federal income tax bracket in 1980 had a marginal tax rate of 70%, but it does not mean that all income above a certain threshold was taxed at that rate. The claim may create confusion by not accurately representing the progressive nature of the tax system.
